Despatches from U.S. Consuls in Sierra Leone, British Africa, 1858-1906

div1.p:
Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone
August 6th 1870

I have the honor to inform the Department, that in consequence of severe illness, I am compelled to return to America, and have authorized Mr John B. Upton the only American Citizen resident here (who is relieving me in my Commercial Capacity) to act during my absence, subject to your approval

I have also the honor to enclose a copy of communication
Honorable Hamilton Fish
Secretary of State
Washington D.C.
Communication addressed to His Excellency Sir Arthur Kennedy C.B. Governor-in-chief of the West African Settlements.

I have the honor to be
Most respectfully
Your obt. servant,
Henry Rider
U.S. Com. Agent. Per. Pro. J. B. Upton

I certify that Henry Rider was totally unable to sign his name on his departure from this Settlement on the 7th instant, owing to Sickness, and that he approved in my presence of the contents of the foregoing letter.
div1.ab:
U.S. Commercial Agency
Sierra Leone
Henry Rider

Received
Mr Rider's return to America.

div1.p: Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone Aug. 6th 1870

I have the honor to inform Your Excellency that in consequence of severe illness I am compelled to return to America, and have authorized Mr John B. Upton to act and perform the duties of my office as Commercial Agent of the United States of America during my absence subject to the approval of my Government
I have to apologize to Your Excellency for not having called upon you before leaving, but my sickness is of such a nature that I am reduced totally helpless.

I have the honor to be
Most respectfully
Your obt. Servt.
Henry Rider
U.S. Com; Agent
Per. Pro. J. B. Upton
